choices.text: Abruptio placenta
Postpartum hemorrhage
Acute Fatty liver of Pregnancy
Hepatitis B

questions.text: Obstetric causes of Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) in pregnancy include all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hepatitis B

 

Causes of AKI in pregnancy

 

  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Abruptio placenta
  • AFLP
  • Severe preeclampsia/ eclampsia
  • PPH
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Thrombotic microangiopathy

 

Ref: Page no 2617, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Hep-B Vaccine should be administered within 24 hours of birth
HBIG should be administered within 12 hours of birth.
Hep-B Vaccine and HBIG should be administered within 12 hours of birth
Hep-B Vaccine and HBIG should be administered within 24 hours of birth

questions.text: A 30y primigravida presents in labor at 38 weeks. The resident notes that she is HBsAg positive. Which of the following statements regarding immunization of a newborn born to a HBsAg positive mother is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hep-B Vaccine and HBIG should be administered within 12 hours of birth)

 

Newborn of HBSAg positive mothers: The following has to be given to reduce the risk of Hepatitis B in the neonate

 

  • Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin (HBIG) 0.5 ml IM (intramuscular) within 12 hours of birth
  • Active immunization with Hep B vaccine (0.5 ml) IM at a separate site at birth.
  • Passive + Active immunization: 85 â€“ 95% effective in preventing transmission.
  • Breastfeeding is not contra-indicated.

 

 

Vaccination schedule of hepatitis B vaccine 

 

 

Reference: Williams Obstetrics 25th edition Page 1065

choices.text: Kidney increases in pregnancy by about 1.5 cm
Pelvicalyceal dilatation is more on the left side than the right side
An increased GFR leads to lower serum creatinine levels
Glycosuria may be seen in up to 50% of pregnant women

questions.text: Which is not seen in pregnancy regarding renal changes in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  Pelvicalyceal dilatation is more on the left side than right side

Physiological changes in the urinary system in pregnancy

  1. Kidneys
    1. Increase in size by about 1.5 cm
    2. Pelvicalyceal dilatation (Right > left)
    3. Increased GFR leading to low creatinine, low BUN and low urea levels
    4. Total volume of urine passed is normal
    5. Enzyme renin is increased
  2. Ureter
    1. Atonic, dilated (Right > left)
  3. Bladder
    1. Mucosa become hyperemic and congested
    2. Increased frequency in the 1st and 3rd trimester
    3. SUI due to urethral sphincter weakness and decreased bladder capacity
  4. Glycosuria
    1. May be seen in up to 50% of pregnant women due to increase in GFR and decreases tubular reabsorption of glucose lowering the renal threshold
  5. Proteinuria
    1. Significant proteinuria (> 300mg/24h) is seen in preeclampsia

Ref: Page no 55, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma

choices.text: Immediate induction of labor
Emergency LSCS
Monitor BP and plan delivery at 37 weeks
Weekly LFT and plan delivery at 38 weeks

questions.text: A 27-year G2P1L1 presents at 33 weeks with itching mainly on the palms of her hands. The itching worsens at night. She gives a similar history in her 1st pregnancy. On examination, her BP is 130/84 mmHg. There is mild icterus and abdominal examination reveals a 32 weeks uterus with fetal heart rate of 140 bpm. Her SGOT is 112 IU/L, SGPT is 124 IU/L and serum bilirubin is 2 mg%. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Weekly LFT and plan delivery at 38 weeks

 

The diagnosis is Obstetric cholestasis

 

Management

    • Symptomatic relief: mollients, Antihistamine, Ursodeoxycholic acid (Relieves pruritus, lowers bile acid and serum liver enzyme levels)
    • Obstetric Management
  • Monitoring with weekly LFT, PT-INR
  • If PT-INR prolonged – offer vitamin K
  • Induction of Labor at 38 weeks
  • Antepartum and Intrapartum fetal monitoring

Reference: - Williams Obstetrics 25th edition, Page no 1060

choices.text: It is the most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy
Itching is typically present on the palms and soles
The recurrence rate in subsequent pregnancies is up to 50%
It is associated with meconium staining of amniotic fluid and fetal death

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding Obstetric Cholestasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is the most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy

 

Obstetric Cholestasis-

  • 2nd most common cause of jaundice in pregnancy (after viral hepatitis)

Clinical Features-

  • Commonly presents in the: 3rd trimester
  • Pruritus

 

Main symptom

  • Generalized but more common on soles and palms
  • Most severe at night
  • Slight jaundice; Associated dark urine, pale stools, steatorrhea and malaise may be seen

 

Investigations-

  • Mildly raised SGOT/ SGPT (usually less than 500)
  • Moderately elevated ALP (Alkaline phosphatase)
  • Moderately elevated serum bilirubin (up to 5 mg %)
  • Raised serum bile acids
      • Most specific investigation
      • Values > 10µmol/L – indicative of increased levels;
      • Values > 40µmol/L – associated with poor perinatal outcome
  • Effect on Pregnancy -
  • Meconium-stained amniotic fluid; Fetal distress; Stillbirths; Increased perinatal mortality rate
  • Management-
  • Symptomatic relief
      • Emollients
      • Antihistamine
      • Ursodeoxycholic acid: Relieves pruritus, lowers bile acid and serum liver enzyme levels
  • Obstetric Management
      • Monitoring with weekly Liver function test
      • If PT-INR prolonged – offer vitamin K
      • Induction of Labor at 38 weeks can be considered.
      • Antepartum and Intrapartum fetal monitoring

 

  • Post Delivery
    • Repeat LFT at 6 weeks postpartum
    • Avoid Estrogen containing contraceptives
    • Recurrence rate in subsequent pregnancy: high (50 – 60%)

 

Reference-: Page 1059, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
HELLP syndrome
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy
Acute viral hepatitis

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her second trimester presents with mildly elevated liver enzymes and itching over her body. She has no history of liver disease. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy

 

Explanation: Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy typically presents in the second or third trimester with itching and elevated liver enzymes but without significant liver damage. It's characterized by impaired bile flow and can lead to adverse fetal outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy: This is diagnosed by the Swansea criteria. Patients with AFLP usually present in the 3rd trimester with jaundice, abdominal pain, vomiting. There is altered liver function along with worsening renal and coagulation parameters. Hypoglycemia is typically seen.
  • Option B: HELLP Syndrome: This is a form of severe preeclampsia so a h/o high BP would usually be mentioned. HELLP syndrome is a triad of Hemolysis, Elevated Liver Enzymes and Low Platelets.
  • Option D: Acute viral hepatitis: This can be seen in any trimester. There is a history of fever, constitutional symptoms and jaundice. Serum bilirubin is raised and AST and ALT are very highly raised.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference- Page no 270, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: It is associated with high fetal and maternal morbidity and mortality
Commonly occurs in the 2nd trimester
It has an association with gestational diabetes mellitus
Less common in multiple pregnancies

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Acute fatty liver of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is associated with high fetal and maternal morbidity and mortality 

 

  • Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy-
  • The most frequent cause of acute liver failure during pregnancy
  • 1 in 10000 pregnancies
  • Recurrence – rare

 

AFLP is diagnosed by Swansea criteria where 6 out of 14 criteria are required to diagnose AFLP

AFLP: Swansea diagnostic criteria

(Six or more in the absence of other explanation)

  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia/polyuria
  • Encephalopathy
  • High bilirubin > 15 micromol/L
  • Hypoglycemia < 4 mmol/L
  • High uric acid > 340 micromol/L
  • Leukocytosis > 11x106/L
  • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
  • High AST/ALT > 42 micromol/L
  • High ammonia >47 micromol/L
  • Renal impairment with creatinine > 150 micromol/L
  • Coagulopathy PT > 14 sec
  • Microvesicular steatosis on liver biopsy

 

Reference- Williams Obstetrics 25th edition, Page no 1061

choices.text: Gestational Diabetes
Hyperemesis gravidarum
Obstetric cholestasis
Pre-eclampsia

questions.text: Liver dysfunction is seen in all of the following in pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gestational Diabetes

 

(Reference- Page no 270, DC Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition)

choices.text: 10%
15%
25%
30%

questions.text: A 23-year G2 is detected to have asymptomatic bacteriuria at 16 weeks. If left untreated, what is her risk of developing symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 30%

 

  • If asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) is not treated, approximately 30 percent of affected women will develop symptomatic infection during pregnancy.
  • Eradication of bacteriuria with antimicrobial agents prevents most of these.
  • The American Academy of Pediatrics and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2017), as well as the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (2019), recommend screening for bacteriuria at the first prenatal visit

 

 

Ref: Page no 2589, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: E. Coli
Klebsiella
Staphylococcus
Proteus

questions.text: The most common species isolated in pregnant women with UTI is:
questions.solution:
Ans: A. E. Coli

UTI in Pregnancy

  • E coli is the most common species isolated in pregnant women
  • 3 types:
  • Asymptomatic Bacteruria
  • Cystitis
  • Acute pyelonephritis

1. Asymptomatic Bacteruria

  • 5% of pregnancies
  • IF untreated: risk of progression to UTI is 25%
  • Diagnosis is made when a routine mid-stream urine culture of a clean voided midstream specimen contains more than 100000 (105) CFU/ ml
  • In a catheter sample, even 100CFU is significant
  • ACOG recommends screening by urine culture at the 1st visit
  • Management: Antibiotics (Culture specific)
  • Avoid antibiotics
  • Tetracyclines
  • Aminoglycosides
  • Fluoroquinolones
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Avoid in 1st trimester

2. Cystitis

  • Infection of the lower urinary tract
  • Burning micturition, frequency, urgency
  • Seen In 1% pregnancies
  • Treatment: culture specific antibiotics
  • DOC: Nitrofurantoin (Avoid towards late term as it may cause neonatal hemolysis)

3. Acute Pyelonephritis

  • Infection of upper urinary tract
  • C/F: fever with chills, , flank pain, malaise, nausea, vomiting
  • Costovertebral tenderness
  • Complications
    • Septic shock
    • ARDS
    • Hemolysis
    • Effect on pregnancy
      • Abortions
      • FGR
      • Preterm labor
      • IUD
  • Treatment:
    • See the table below
    • Mainstay is Fluid therapy

Management of Pregnant women with Acute Pyelonephritis (Very important table)

** Recurrent infection—either covert or symptomatic—is common and develops in 30 to 40 percent of women following completion of pyelonephritis treatment. Unless other measures are taken to ensure urine sterility, nitrofurantoin, 100 mg orally at bedtime given for the remainder of the pregnancy, reduces bacteriuria recurrence**

 

 

Ref: Page no 2594, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

UTI in Pregnancy

  • E coli is the most common species isolated in pregnant women
  • 3 types:

choices.text: Oral antibiotics once afebrile
Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures
Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; IV crystalloids can be given.
Discharge if afebrile for 72h, continue anti-microbials for 5 days

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Discharge if afebrile for 72h, continue anti-microbials for 5 days

 

UTI in Pregnancy

 

  • E coli is the most common species isolated in pregnant women
  • 3 types:
    • Asymptomatic Bacteruria
    • Cystitis
    • Acute pyelonephritis

1. Asymptomatic Bacteruria

  • 5% of pregnancies
  • IF untreated: risk of progression to UTI is 25%
  • Diagnosis is made when a routine mid-stream urine culture of a clean voided midstream specimen contains more than 100000 (105) CFU/ ml
  • In a catheter sample, even 100CFU is significant
  • ACOG recommends screening by urine culture at the 1st visit
  • Management: Antibiotics (Culture specific)
  • Avoid antibiotics
  • Tetracyclines
  • Aminoglycosides
  • Fluoroquinolones
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Avoid in 1st trimester

2. Cystitis

  • Infection of the lower urinary tract
  • Burning micturition, frequency, urgency
  • Seen In 1% pregnancies
  • Treatment: culture specific antibiotics
  • DOC: Nitrofurantoin (Avoid towards late term as it may cause neonatal hemolysis)

3. Acute Pyelonephritis

  • Infection of upper urinary tract
  • C/F: fever with chills, , flank pain, malaise, nausea, vomiting
  • Costovertebral tenderness
  • Complications
    • Septic shock
    • ARDS
    • Hemolysis
    • Effect on pregnancy
      • Abortions
      • FGR
      • Preterm labor
      • IUD
  • Treatment: 
    • See the table below
    • Mainstay is Fluid therapy

 

 

Management of Pregnant women with Acute Pyelonephritis (Very important table)

 

** Recurrent infectionâ€”either covert or symptomaticâ€”is common and develops in 30 to 40 percent of women following completion of pyelonephritis treatment. Unless other measures are taken to ensure urine sterility, nitrofurantoin, 100 mg orally at bedtime given for the remainder of the pregnancy, reduces bacteriuria recurrence**

 

Discharge is considered after 24â€“48h afebrile, and antimicrobials are continued for 10â€“14 days â€” not just 5 days.

 

Ref: Page no 2594, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Women with solid organ transplant have higher severe maternal morbidity rates
There is an increased incidence of pre-eclampsia
A rise in serum creatinine levels in pregnancy could be a sign of acute rejection.
The rates of cesarean section are not higher in women with transplanted kidneys

questions.text: A 34y woman presents at 10 weeks pregnancy. She is a renal transplant recipient and had a transplant 3 years earlier. On examination her BP is 130/ 80mmHg. The ultrasound shows a single live fetus of 10 weeks. Which of the following is incorrect regarding pregnancy in a renal transplant patient?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. The rates of cesarean section are not higher in women with transplanted kidneys

  • Women with solid organ transplant have higher severe maternal morbidity rates
  • Close surveillance is necessary
  • Asymptomatic bacteriuria is treated, and if it is recurrent, suppressive treatment is given for the remainder of the pregnancy
  • Serial hepatic enzyme concentrations and blood counts are monitored for toxic effects of azathioprine and cyclosporine (if the patient is on these drugs)
  • Gestational diabetes is more common if corticosteroids are taken
  • Preeclampsia is more common
  • Surveillance for opportunistic infections from herpesvirus, cytomegalovirus, and toxoplasmosis is important because these infections are common.
  • Renal function is monitored, and the GFR usually increases 20 to 25 percent
  • If a significant rise in the serum creatinine level is detected, its cause must be determined. Possibilities include
    • Acute rejection
    • Cyclosporine toxicity
    • Preeclampsia
    • Infection
    • Urinary tract obstruction.
  • Evidence of pyelonephritis or graft rejection should prompt admission for aggressive management. Imaging studies and kidney biopsy may be indicated.
  • The woman is carefully monitored for development or worsening of underlying hypertension, and especially of superimposed preeclampsia.
  • Vigilant fetal surveillance is indicated because of the higher incidences of fetal-growth restriction and preterm delivery.
  • Although cesarean delivery is reserved for obstetrical indications, occasionally the transplanted kidney obstructs labor, and the overall cesarean delivery rate approaches 80 percent

 

 

Ref: page 2601, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Abruptio placenta
Postpartum haemorrhage
Acute Fatty liver of Pregnancy
Antiphospholipid Antibody syndrome

questions.text: Obstetric causes of Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) in pregnancy include except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Antiphospholipid Antibody syndrome

 

Causes of AKI in pregnancy

  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Abruptio placenta
  • AFLP
  • Severe preeclampsia/ eclampsia
  • PPH
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Thrombotic microangipathies

 

APS causes chronic thrombotic events and pregnancy loss, but is not an acute obstetric cause of AKI. Abruptio placenta, PPH, AFLP all cause sudden hypoperfusion or organ injury, leading to AKI.

 

Ref: Page no 2617, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: 65-75%
75-85%
85-95%
95-100%

questions.text: A 24y lady G2 is detected to be HBsAg positive on routine antenatal screening. She is very concerned regarding the risk of vertical transmission and is counseled that both active and passive immunization will be given to the baby at birth. She asks if the baby receives this immunization, by how much would the risk of transmission be reduced?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 85-95%

Newborns of seropositive mothers

  • Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin (HBIG) 0.5 ml IM (intramuscular) within 12 hours of birth
  • Active immunization with Hep B vaccine (0.5 ml) IM at a separate site at birth
  • Passive + Active immunization: 85 – 95% effective in preventing transmission
  • Breastfeeding is not contra-indicated

 

Reference: Page 1065, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Hepatitis A
Hepatitis B
Hepatitis C
Hepatitis E

questions.text: Fulminant hepatitis is associated with which of the following in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hepatitis E

 

Hepatitis E infection during pregnancy, especially in the third trimester with genotype 1, has a more severe outcome that might lead to fulminant hepatitis, increasing maternal and fetal mortality.

 

(Reference: Page np 1066, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Which is correct regarding Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Occurs late in pregnancy 

 

  • Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy-
  • The most frequent cause of acute liver failure during pregnancy
  • 1 in 10000 pregnancies
  • Recurrence – rare

 

AFLP is diagnosed by Swansea criteria where 6 out of 14 criteria are required to diagnose AFLP

AFLP: Swansea diagnostic criteria

(Six or more in the absence of other explanation)

  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia/polyuria
  • Encephalopathy
  • High bilirubin > 15 micromol/L
  • Hypoglycemia < 4 mmol/L
  • High uric acid > 340 micromol/L
  • Leukocytosis > 11x106/L
  • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
  • High AST/ALT > 42 micromol/L
  • High ammonia >47 micromol/L
  • Renal impairment with creatinine > 150 micromol/L
  • Coagulopathy PT > 14 sec
  • Microvesicular steatosis on liver biopsy

 

Reference- Williams Obstetrics 25th edition, Page no 1061

choices.text: Adefovir
Lamivudine
Telbivudine
Tenofovir

questions.text: The drug of choice to reduce perinatal transmission in Hepatitis B in pregnant women with high viral load is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tenofovir

  • The drug of choice to reduce vertical transmission in women with high viral load is tenofovir.
  • Passive immunization with HBIG (Hepatitis B immunoglobulin) within 12 hours of birth also reduces the risk of vertical transmission.

 

Reference- Williams Obstetrics 25th edition, Page no 1064,

choices.text: Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy
HELLP syndrome
Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy
Viral Hepatitis

questions.text: A 28-year Primigravida with twin pregnancy presents at 34 weeks with vomiting and malaise for 1 week. On examination, her BP is 136/ 90 mmHg. She is icteric and abdominal examination reveals an over distended uterus with the first twin in cephalic presentation. FHR of both twins are between 140-150 bpm. Her investigations reveal a serum bilirubin of 5mg%. SGOT – 780 IU/L; SGPT – 800 IU/L, RBS is 45 mg%, platelet count is 96000/ mm3 and urine routine is normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP)

 

  • The diagnosis is AFLP.
  • It is unlikely to be viral hepatitis as in viral hepatitis the transaminases are > 2000 IU/L and serum bilirubin is also very high (> 10 mg%)
  • Hypoglycemia is an important feature of AFLP
  • AFLP can be associated with pre-eclampsia

Now, we use the Swansea criteria to diagnose AFLP. 6 of 14 criteria need to be there.

AFLP: Swansea diagnostic criteria

(Six or more in the absence of other explanation)

  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia/polyuria
  • Encephalopathy
  • High bilirubin > 15 micromol/L
  • Hypoglycemia < 4 mmol/L
  • High uric acid > 340 micromol/L
  • Leukocytosis > 11x106/L
  • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
  • High AST/ALT > 42 micromol/L
  • High ammonia >47 micromol/L
  • Renal impairment with creatinine > 150 micromol/L
  • Coagulopathy PT > 14 sec
  • Microvesicular steatosis on liver biopsy

 

Reference- Williams Obstetrics 25th edition, Page 1061

Hb is 8g%, platelet count is 90000/ mm3, RBS is 40 mg/dl. AST is 85 and ALT is 80. Peripheral smear shows normocytic normochromic anemia. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Ans. B. AFLP

30%

questions.text: A 23-year G2 is detected to have asymptomatic bacteriuria at 16 weeks. If left untreated, what is her risk of developing symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 25%

 

Explanation

 

  • If asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) is not treated, approximately 25 percent of affected women will develop symptomatic infection during pregnancy.
  • Eradication of bacteriuria with antimicrobial agents prevents most of these.
  • The American Academy of Pediatrics and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2017), as well as the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (2019), recommend screening for bacteriuria at the first prenatal visit

 

Ref: Page no 2589, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: E. Coli
Klebsiella
Staphylococcus
Proteus

questions.text: The most common species isolated in pregnant women with UTI is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. E. Coli

UTI in Pregnancy

  • E coli is the most common species isolated in pregnant women
  • 3 types:
  • Asymptomatic Bacteriuria
  • Cystitis
  • Acute pyelonephritis

 

  1. Asymptomatic Bacteriuria
  • 5% of pregnancies
  • IF untreated: risk of progression to UTI is 25%
  • Diagnosis is made when a routine mid-stream urine culture of a clean voided midstream specimen contains more than 100000 (105) CFU/ ml
  • In a catheter sample, even 100 CFU is significant
  • ACOG recommends screening by urine culture at the 1st visit
  • Management: Antibiotics (Culture specific)
  • Avoid antibiotics
  • Tetracyclines
  • Aminoglycosides
  • Fluoroquinolones
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Avoid in 1st trimester
  1. Cystitis
  • Infection of the lower urinary tract
  • Burning micturition, frequency, urgency
  • Seen In 1% pregnancies
  • Treatment: culture specific antibiotics
  • DOC: Nitrofurantoin (Avoid towards late term as it may cause neonatal hemolysis)

 

  1. Acute Pyelonephritis
      • Infection of upper urinary tract
      • C/F: fever with chills, flank pain, malaise, nausea, vomiting
      • Costovertebral tenderness
      • Complications
      • Septic shock
      • ARDS
      • Hemolysis
      • Effect on pregnancy
          1. Abortions
          2. FGR
          3. Preterm labor
          4. IUD
      • Treatment:

Mainstay is Fluid therapy

 

Management of Pregnant women with Acute Pyelonephritis


** Recurrent infection—either covert or symptomatic—is common and develops in 30 to 40 percent of women following completion of pyelonephritis treatment. Unless other measures are taken to ensure urine sterility, nitrofurantoin, 100 mg orally at bedtime given for the remainder of the pregnancy, reduces bacteriuria recurrence**

 

Ref: Page no 2594, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Preeclampsia
Chronic kidney disease
Acute pyelonephritis
Glomerulonephritis

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman presents with new onset hypertension, proteinuria, and elevated serum creatinine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Preeclampsia

 

Explanation: Preeclampsia is characterized by new-onset hypertension and proteinuria after 20 weeks of gestation. Elevated serum creatinine may also be present. This condition requires careful management due to risks to both the mother and fetus.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: CKD is characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. While patients with CKD can present with hypertension, proteinuria, and elevated serum creatinine, the history of pregnancy and the acute presentation make preeclampsia a more likely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C: Acute Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the kidneys that can cause flank pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, and urinary symptoms, in addition to elevated serum creatinine and sometimes proteinuria. However, the key distinguishing feature of acute pyelonephritis is usually a fever and signs of infection, which are not mentioned in the scenario.

 

Option D: Glomerulonephritis is an inflammation of the glomeruli in the kidneys. It can cause hypertension, proteinuria, and elevated serum creatinine. However, in the context of pregnancy, especially without a prior history of renal disease, preeclampsia is a more common cause of these symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preeclampsia is defined as Hypertension with Proteinuria in pregnancy

 

  • Blood pressure criteria includes systolic BP ≥ 140 mmHg or diastolic BP ≥ 90mmHg or both on 2 occasions at least 4h apart after 20 weeks gestation with previously normal BP
  • Proteinuria is defined as a 24h urine collection > 300mg protein OR single voided urine protein/ creatinine ration ≥ 0.3 Or dipstick reading of 2 + (Recent ACOG guidelines).

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 720

choices.text: Hepatitis A
Hepatitis B
Hepatitis C
Any of the above

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents with jaundice, fatigue, and elevated liver enzymes. She reports a recent history of consuming seafood at a local restaurant. Which type of viral hepatitis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hepatitis A

 

Explanation: Hepatitis A is typically transmitted via the fecal-oral route, often through contaminated food or water. The recent history of consuming seafood, a common vehicle for Hepatitis A transmission, along with the presentation of jaundice, fatigue, and elevated liver enzymes, strongly suggests Hepatitis

 

Option B, C and D: Hepatitis B and C are more commonly transmitted through blood and bodily fluids, and while they can cause similar symptoms, the patient's history makes them less likely in this case. Hepatitis E, also transmitted feco-orally and linked to contaminated water, is a consideration, but Hepatitis A is more commonly associated with seafood consumption

 

Pregnant women, especially those in the second or third trimester, are at a higher risk of developing severe disease if they contract Hepatitis E. The infection can lead to fulminant hepatic failure, a life-threatening condition characterized by rapid deterioration of liver function. The mortality rate for pregnant women with Hepatitis E, particularly in the third trimester, can be significantly higher than in the general population. Hepatitis E is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route, typically via contaminated water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A is typically transmitted via the fecal-oral route, often through contaminated food or water. The recent history of consuming seafood, a common vehicle for Hepatitis A transmission, along with the presentation of jaundice, fatigue, and elevated liver enzymes, strongly suggests Hepatitis

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition Pg 1062
